Education: In my thesis, I argue that the performance of incremental view maintenance in data warehouses depends on system aspects of the database, such as availability of indices, sizes of the database tables and sizes of the database updates. I also argue that the choice of how to maintain a view (incrementally or by re-evaluating the view query) should be left to the database optimizer to make, which has knowledge of, and access to, all parameters that may affect this choice. I built the RHODES relational database query optimizer that supports materialized views and their maintenance. A major part of my thesis work concerned experimental validation of incremental algorithms using the AIX DB2 database system on the TPC-D database benchmark.

My master's thesis integrated research in the area of object-oriented query languages for database systems with research in the area of updating databases. In particular, I described a framework for updated in F-logic, an object-oriented logic-based query language. This framework allowed, among other things, the specification of hypothetical queries. A hypothetical query asks the database to predict what would happen, if something were true, even though it may not necessarily be true.
Experience: I worked as a Member of Technical Staff in the database research department at AT&T Labs. My research interests during this time included directories and directory-enabled applications, and resulted in two US Patents.  All related development efforts was done using Java, HTML, Perl, CGI and the Netscape Directory Server.

During this year, I worked on how we can use a database visualization system to visualize portions of the internet explored during a browsing session. We modified one of the existing web browsers to communicate, as the user browses, the URL, title and anchors of each document fetched. The system provided graphical presentations of the history of the navigation and multiple views of the structure of the explored portion of the web. Queries of the visual language GraphLog were used to query and reformat these visualizations.
